attributes.title: Addictions regulation processses  : emotional vulnerability factors and craving

summary.value:
Affectivity, alexithymia and craving: a systematic review

Background: Craving is defined as a “strong desire or urge to consume a substance” (APA, 2013). It is a central symptom in substance use disorders. Researches on substance cues reactivity in addiction showed the influence of situational and affective cues-elicited craving (e.g., Preston et al., 2009) and highlighted strong links between negative affects (NA) and craving reactivity (e.g., Cooney et al., 1997). NA and craving are both know to be associated with substance use and to interfere with intervention outcomes. However, it is still not known how these variables relate to each other and if some others affective variables, for instance positive affects (PA) and alexithymia, may play an important role.
Methods: Studies were identified by searching PubMed/MEDLINE, PsycINFO and Web of Science using PRISMA procedure and PICOTS framework. There were included if they assessed craving and affectivity (trait or state) or alexithymia  and sample composed of substance use disorders participants.  
Results: As much as twenty of the twenty three studies selected show a correlation between affectivity, alexithymia and craving; highlighting 55% of direct links and 48% of partial links. Studies on negative affects (78%) put forth their causal link  with craving, while studies on positive affectivity (26%) present it as a moderating element. Studies on alexithymia (17%) show its effects on emotional reactivity only in negative affectivity situations.
Conclusions: Our review confirms the impact of emotional processes on craving by highlighting the distinct and interdependent roles of negative affectivity, positive affectivity and alexithymia. Further investigations should included longitudinal design to determine directional pathways from affectivity to craving and clarify its moderating and/or mediating effects according to substances types.

registration_responses.summary:
Affectivity, alexithymia and craving: a systematic review

Background: Craving is defined as a “strong desire or urge to consume a substance” (APA, 2013). It is a central symptom in substance use disorders. Researches on substance cues reactivity in addiction showed the influence of situational and affective cues-elicited craving (e.g., Preston et al., 2009) and highlighted strong links between negative affects (NA) and craving reactivity (e.g., Cooney et al., 1997). NA and craving are both know to be associated with substance use and to interfere with intervention outcomes. However, it is still not known how these variables relate to each other and if some others affective variables, for instance positive affects (PA) and alexithymia, may play an important role.
Methods: Studies were identified by searching PubMed/MEDLINE, PsycINFO and Web of Science using PRISMA procedure and PICOTS framework. There were included if they assessed craving and affectivity (trait or state) or alexithymia  and sample composed of substance use disorders participants.  
Results: As much as twenty of the twenty three studies selected show a correlation between affectivity, alexithymia and craving; highlighting 55% of direct links and 48% of partial links. Studies on negative affects (78%) put forth their causal link  with craving, while studies on positive affectivity (26%) present it as a moderating element. Studies on alexithymia (17%) show its effects on emotional reactivity only in negative affectivity situations.
Conclusions: Our review confirms the impact of emotional processes on craving by highlighting the distinct and interdependent roles of negative affectivity, positive affectivity and alexithymia. Further investigations should included longitudinal design to determine directional pathways from affectivity to craving and clarify its moderating and/or mediating effects according to substances types.

attributes.title: Social isolation and vocabulary development: Insights from monolingual and bilingual families with varying SES in the UK

q1.value: Social isolation and vocabulary development: Insights from monolingual and bilingual families with varying SES in the UK

q2.value: Shannon P Gibson, Natalia Kartushina, Julien Mayor, Nayeliz Gonzalez-Gomez

q3.value: A convincing body of research has shown that shared book reading in early childhood promotes language development (O'Farrelly et al., 2018; Sénéchal and Young, 2008). Yet, families with low socioeconomic status (SES) might provide a less stimulating environment for language development for their children, as compared to families with high SES, as they have sparser access to books and engage less frequently in shared reading interactions (Kelly et al., 2011, Melhuish et al., 2008). For instance, it has been estimated that by the age of 4 years, toddlers from low SES families have heard about 30 million less words than peers from higher SES families (Hart and Risley, 1995). The current longitudinal study aims to assess home activities and interactions that parents engage in with their 8 to 36-month-old infants during the nursery closure and social isolation period due to the COVID-19 outbreak in the UK, and to examine their role in early vocabulary development of monolingual and bilingual infants across varying in SES-background families. This is part of a collaborative project with different labs around the world, based on the initiative of the Department of Psychology at the University of Oslo.

q4.value:
We expect that parents from lower SES backgrounds will engage less frequently in shared book reading activities and structured parent-infant interactions than parents from higher SES backgrounds.
We hypothesise that infants in lower SES families might be exposed to TV/cartoons more than infants in higher SES families.
We expect that infants growing up in lower SES families will have smaller gains in both receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes than infants growing up in higher SES families.
We expect that the frequency of shared book reading will explain more variance in vocabulary size of each language than the frequency of other child-parent activities (see Montag et al., 2015).
We predict that more frequent use of dialogue style in shared book reading in each language will be related to large gains in expressive vocabulary (Flack et al., 2015).
We expect that more frequent exposure to TV/baby cartoons will be related to smaller gains in receptive vocabulary (cf Kuhl et al., 2003).
In most cases, minority language exposure will increase due to the isolation from the majority language 
In minority-language households, we expect that vocabulary in the minority language will develop more, given the changes in the amount of exposure.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study has a regression design: we will examine whether family's SES, frequency of shared book reading, structured plays and TV/baby cartoons exposure modulate gains in receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes for monolingual and bilingual toddlers.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Parents/guardians of 8-to-36-month-old infants from the Oxford Brookes BabyLab database will be invited to participate in this study. We will also contact parents through social media (i.e. Facebook and Twitter). Parents will be asked to complete a questionnaire at the beginning of the school and nursery closure period (Time 1) and again, once social distancing rules cease and the schools and nurseries reopen (Time 2). The questionnaires at Time 1 will include a vocabulary questionnaire (the Oxford Communicative Development Inventory O-CDI; Hamilton, Plunkett, & Schafer, 2000), a family background questionnaire (which will include information about siblings' gender and age, and family's SES), the Early Parenting Attitudes Questionnaire (Hembacher & Frank, 2018), four questions about use of infant directed speech, and a measure of smartphone use. At Time 2, we will repeat the O-CDI, screen time measure, and ask what type of activities parents engaged in with their child (and activity frequency) during the isolation period. Parents of children who are exposed to more than one language will be asked to complete either a bilingual, trilingual or multilingual (four language) adaptation of the O-CDI. These questionnaires include additional columns for the parent to report whether the words are understood or said in any of the child’s languages. These parents will also be asked to provide a phone number to complete the Language Exposure Questionnaire (LEQ; Bosch & Sebastián-Gallés, 1997) via phone after the Time 2 questionnaire. The O-CDI will provide us with an estimate of a child's comprehensive and productive vocabulary size in each language at Time 1 and Time 2. Children who were born more than two weeks before term and children with auditory or visual deficits will be excluded from analyses.

q13.value: We will stop data collection after completion of questionnaires at Time 2 (i.e. as soon as the social distancing rules cease and the schools and nurseries are reopened in the UK). We will aim to invite as many participants as possible.

question.value:
Our dependent variable is the total number of words that parents reported that their child understands (between 8 and 18 months of age) and produces (between 8 and 36 months of age) in each of their languages. For bilingual infants, we will also calculate the total comprehensive and productive vocabulary size (i.e. summing the number of words known and said in English and the additional language), conceptual vocabulary size (i.e. number of concepts known across both languages) and percentage of translation equivalents (i.e. dividing the number of words for which the infant knew the label in both languages by the total vocabulary size).   

Our predictors are: the frequency of shared book reading during the social isolation period; the frequency of structured child-parent interactions; the amount of exposure to TV/cartoons. If the sample size permits, for those infants whose parents engage in shared book reading, we will include the type of reading as a factor (more verbalisations and dialogue-type of reading should result in larger gains in vocabulary). For bilingual infants, we will also consider the percentage of exposure to each language as a predictor. 

Maternal education (varying from 1 - Primary school to 8 - PhD) will be used as a proxy of SES and will be included as a predictor in the analyses.

We will also count the number of days between T1 and T2 (Gap_days) and will include it as a co-variate in the analyses.

First, we will examine the number of participants and the distribution of the SES backgrounds across the 8 possible categories (coded as a continuous variable, varying from 1 - Primary school to 8 - PhD). If the distribution is not homogeneous and we have relatively few answers per category (less than 5), then we will recode the SES variable into a binary factor (low [from 1 to 4], and high [from 5 to 8]). 

Then, we will examine the role of different activities that parents have engaged in during the social isolation period and the gain score in their vocabulary size. Modality (receptive vs expressive) will be included as a factor for 8-18-month-old infants and Child will be included as a random variable. We also will model a possible interaction between Frequency_read and Modality (cf Karras et al, 2005).

We will also include Gap_days as a co-variate in the analyses, as we expect larger gains of more days have passed between Time 1 and Time 2.

Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Modality + Modality:Frequency_read+Gap_days+(1|Child), data=8_18_mo_data

If the model does not converge, then the interaction term will be removed from the model and the analyses will be performed for each modality separately.

Second, we will perform similar analyses for the expressive vocabulary (modality will be removed). For this, we will merge data on expressive vocabulary from 8-18 and 19-36-months of age.

Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Gap_days, data=8_36_mo_data

For those infants whose parents do engage in shared book reading, we will examine the role of type of reading and frequency of reading in each data sample.

Gains~Type_reading+Frequency_read+Maternal_educ+Gap_days

For bilingual infants, these analyses will be repeated for gains in vocabulary size in each language, total vocabulary size and conceptual vocabulary size. We will also repeat these analyses for changes in the proportion of translation equivalents. The percentage of exposure to each language will also be considered as a predictor in these models. 

In a separate series of analyses, we will examine differences in everyday activities across families from different SES backgrounds. If the data permits (see above), then correlation analyses will be performed between Maternal_educ (6 categories, coded as a continuous variable) and the frequency of different activities during the lockdown period; if not, then a binary factor of SES will be used and then all the data will be split in two (families with high and families with low SES).

q20.value:
For each child, the vocabulary size in percentile at Time 1 will be subtracted from the vocabulary size at Time 2, separately for receptive and expressive modality. As a result, we will obtain two gain scores (one for receptive and one for expressive vocabulary) for 8 to 18 month-old infants and one gain score for 19 to 36-month-old infants. The gain scores will be used in the statistical analyses. If we observe that some infants have close-to-ceiling vocabulary size at Time 1, then we will standardise the vocabulary score at both times and a standardised measure of gains will be used in the analyses: (voc_std(T2)-voc_std(T1)).

For bilingual infants, these transformations will be repeated to calculate gains in vocabulary size in each language, total vocabulary size and conceptual vocabulary size. We will also calculate changes in the proportion of translation equivalents from T1 to T2.

q22.value: Infants who are born more than two weeks before term, and infants with auditory or visual deficits will be excluded from analyses.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete the questionnaires at both time points, the data will be excluded from analyses.

q24.value:
In the exploratory analyses, we will examine the role of outdoor activities (type and frequency) in children's well-being and self-regulation.

In addition, we will examine whether there are differences between those infants who were already attending nursery before the coronavirus outbreak and those who did not.

If the sample permits, we will explore language development during the isolation period for infants exposed to three or four languages.

We will also explore the role of siblings in language development during the social isolation period. 

We will also examine whether smartphone use is negatively correlated with language development.

q25.value:
This is part of a collaborative project with different labs around the world, based on the initiative of the Department of Psychology at the University of Oslo.

References
Bosch, L. & Sebastian-Galles, N. (1997). Native language recognition abilities in 4- month old infants from monolingual and bilingual environments. Cognition, 65, 33–69

Flack, Z. M., Field, A. P., & Horst, J. S. (2018). The effects of shared storybook reading on word learning: A meta-analysis. Developmental Psychology, 54(7), 1334–1346. https://doi.org/10.1037/dev0000512

Hamilton, A., Plunkett, K., & Schafer, G., (2000). Infant vocabulary development assessed with a British Communicative Development Inventory: Lower scores in the UK than the USA. Journal of Child Language, 27, 689-705

Hart, B., & Risley, T. R. (1995). Meaningful differences in the everyday experiences of young American children (Paul H. Brookes).

Hembacher, E., & Frank, M. C. (2018). The early parenting attitudes questionnaire: Measuring intuitive theories of parenting and child development.

Karrass, J., & Braungart-Rieker, J. M. (2005). Effects of shared parent–infant book reading on early language acquisition. Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology, 26(2), 133–148. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appdev.2004.12.003 

Kelly, Y., Sacker, A., Bono, E. D., Francesconi, M., & Marmot, M. (2011). What role for the home learning environment and parenting in reducing the socioeconomic gradient in child development? Findings from the Millennium Cohort Study. Archives of Disease in Childhood, 96(9), 832–837. https://doi.org/10.1136/adc.2010.195917

Kuhl, P. K., Tsao, F.-M., & Liu, H.-M. (2003). Foreign-language experience in infancy: Effects of short-term exposure and social interaction on phonetic learning. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 100(15), 9096–9101. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1532872100 

Melhuish, E. C., Phan, M. B., Sylva, K., Sammons, P., Siraj‐Blatchford, I., & Taggart, B. (2008). Effects of the Home Learning Environment and Preschool Center Experience upon Literacy and Numeracy Development in Early Primary School. Journal of Social Issues, 64(1), 95–114. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-4560.2008.00550.x 

Montag, J. L., Jones, M. N., & Smith, L. B. (2015). The words children hear: Picture books and the statistics for language learning. Psychological Science, 26(9), 1489–1496. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797615594361 

O’Farrelly, C., Doyle, O., Victory, G., & Palamaro-Munsell, E. (2018). Shared reading in infancy and later development: Evidence from an early intervention. Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology, 54, 69–83. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appdev.2017.12.001

Sénéchal, M., & Young, L. (2008). The Effect of Family Literacy Interventions on Children’s Acquisition of Reading From Kindergarten to Grade 3: A Meta-Analytic Review: Review of Educational Research. https://doi.org/10.3102/0034654308320319

For bilingual infants, we will also calculate the total comprehensive and productive vocabulary size (i.e. summing the number of words known and said in English and the additional language), conceptual vocabulary size (i.e. number of concepts known across both languages) and percentage of translation equivalents (i.e. dividing the number of words for which the infant knew the label in both languages by the total vocabulary size).

First, we will examine the number of participants and the distribution of the SES backgrounds across the 8 possible categories (coded as a continuous variable, varying from 1 - Primary school to 8 - PhD). If the distribution is not homogeneous and we have relatively few answers per category (less than 5), then we will recode the SES variable into a binary factor (low [from 1 to 4], and high [from 5 to 8]). 

Then, we will examine the role of different activities that parents have engaged in during the social isolation period and the gain score in their vocabulary size. Modality (receptive vs expressive) will be included as a factor for 8-18-month-old infants and Child will be included as a random variable. We also will model a possible interaction between Frequency_read and Modality (cf Karras et al, 2005).

We will also include Gap_days as a co-variate in the analyses, as we expect larger gains of more days have passed between Time 1 and Time 2.

Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Modality + Modality:Frequency_read+Gap_days+(1|Child), data=8_18_mo_data

If the model does not converge, then the interaction term will be removed from the model and the analyses will be performed for each modality separately.

Second, we will perform similar analyses for the expressive vocabulary (modality will be removed). For this, we will merge data on expressive vocabulary from 8-18 and 19-36-months of age.

Gains~Frequency_read+Frequency_interaction+Frequency_TV+Frequency_outdoor+Maternal_educ+Gap_days, data=8_36_mo_data

For those infants whose parents do engage in shared book reading, we will examine the role of type of reading and frequency of reading in each data sample.

Gains~Type_reading+Frequency_read+Maternal_educ+Gap_days

For bilingual infants, these analyses will be repeated for gains in vocabulary size in each language, total vocabulary size and conceptual vocabulary size. We will also repeat these analyses for changes in the proportion of translation equivalents. The percentage of exposure to each language will also be considered as a predictor in these models. 

In a separate series of analyses, we will examine differences in everyday activities across families from different SES backgrounds. If the data permits (see above), then correlation analyses will be performed between Maternal_educ (6 categories, coded as a continuous variable) and the frequency of different activities during the lockdown period; if not, then a binary factor of SES will be used and then all the data will be split in two (families with high and families with low SES).

q3.value: We know that about 5% of the population is at high risk of overshopping (Maraz, Griffiths and Demetrovics, 2016). One of the most common risk factors for compulsive buying is distress (Rose and Segrist, 2012), and employing maladaptive strategies to cope with distress (passive-avoidance, wishful thinking, and self-criticism) (Otero-López and Villardefrancos, 2014). We know that the use of maladaptive strategies increases under chronic stress (Wadsworth, 2015), such as the result of the measures being currently taken worldwide to stop the COVID-19 pandemic. Consequently, it is expected that shopping behaviour (tendency and spending) also increases during the pandemic, especially among those with a pre-existing tendency for compulsive buying. However, a complex model including the levels of (general) distress and coping has never been tested before. Even less attention has been paid to online shopping, which is likely to be a popular option during social isolation measures. Therefore the current study aims to test the effect of distress and coping style on shopping behaviour during the pandemic.

q4.value:
1. compulsive buying tendencies increase under distress for everyone
2. among those with pathological buying tendencies the shopping behaviour (tendency and spending) will increase under distress 
3. maladaptive coping increases the likelihood of overshopping as a result of distress

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: cross-sectional survey over an extended period of time. A new cohort of participants assessed via MTurk every 3 days until the end of the epidemic in the USA + 6 weeks.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Recruitment via MTurk, compensation of $3 per participant. Inclusion criteria are age of 18+ and US-based IP address. Recruitment starts immediately after obtaining ethical permission and lasts until the official end of the pandemic in the USA + 6 weeks

q13.value: Sample size depends on the duration of the pandemic and funding. Currently we have a budget to collect data from 1750 participants (30 weeks, every 3 days a cohort of 25 participants). This may increase with more funding and decrease if the pandemic ends earlier. It is also possible that if assessments will be spaced out if the outbreak appears to last longer than expected and no further funding is available.

q14.value: Our goal was to maximise the sample size and optimise timing given the limited budget.

question.value: perceived stress (PSC) as predictor, coping (CISS, factors) as mediator and online shopping (COSS) as outcome in the first, and offline shopping (BCBS) as outcome in the second model. Covariates are age, gender, SES. Other questions will be past-week spending, debt, and social desirability (MCSDSSF)

H1: correlation
H2: correlation (restricted to compulsive buyers)
H3: SEM

q22.value: In total 4 attention check items are hidden among regular questions - scoring 2 or more errors or having high social desirability score (higher than 7 on the scale of 1 to 10) will lead to exclusion from the data.

q23.value: There cannot be missing data (except for optional items) by design.

registration_responses.q3: We know that about 5% of the population is at high risk of overshopping (Maraz, Griffiths and Demetrovics, 2016). One of the most common risk factors for compulsive buying is distress (Rose and Segrist, 2012), and employing maladaptive strategies to cope with distress (passive-avoidance, wishful thinking, and self-criticism) (Otero-López and Villardefrancos, 2014). We know that the use of maladaptive strategies increases under chronic stress (Wadsworth, 2015), such as the result of the measures being currently taken worldwide to stop the COVID-19 pandemic. Consequently, it is expected that shopping behaviour (tendency and spending) also increases during the pandemic, especially among those with a pre-existing tendency for compulsive buying. However, a complex model including the levels of (general) distress and coping has never been tested before. Even less attention has been paid to online shopping, which is likely to be a popular option during social isolation measures. Therefore the current study aims to test the effect of distress and coping style on shopping behaviour during the pandemic.
registration_responses.q4:
1. compulsive buying tendencies increase under distress for everyone
2. among those with pathological buying tendencies the shopping behaviour (tendency and spending) will increase under distress 
3. maladaptive coping increases the likelihood of overshopping as a result of distress
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Sample size depends on the duration of the pandemic and funding. Currently we have a budget to collect data from 1750 participants (30 weeks, every 3 days a cohort of 25 participants). This may increase with more funding and decrease if the pandemic ends earlier. It is also possible that if assessments will be spaced out if the outbreak appears to last longer than expected and no further funding is available.
registration_responses.q14: Our goal was to maximise the sample size and optimise timing given the limited budget.
registration_responses.q22: In total 4 attention check items are hidden among regular questions - scoring 2 or more errors or having high social desirability score (higher than 7 on the scale of 1 to 10) will lead to exclusion from the data.
registration_responses.q23: There cannot be missing data (except for optional items) by design.
registration_responses.q8.question: cross-sectional survey over an extended period of time. A new cohort of participants assessed via MTurk every 3 days until the end of the epidemic in the USA + 6 weeks.
registration_responses.q12.question: Recruitment via MTurk, compensation of $3 per participant. Inclusion criteria are age of 18+ and US-based IP address. Recruitment starts immediately after obtaining ethical permission and lasts until the official end of the pandemic in the USA + 6 weeks
registration_responses.q17.question: perceived stress (PSC) as predictor, coping (CISS, factors) as mediator and online shopping (COSS) as outcome in the first, and offline shopping (BCBS) as outcome in the second model. Covariates are age, gender, SES. Other questions will be past-week spending, debt, and social desirability (MCSDSSF)
registration_responses.q19.question:
H1: correlation
H2: correlation (restricted to compulsive buyers)
H3: SEM

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
Counterfactual Curiosity - One-shot Task

This experiment is a follow-up to the five experiments reported in our pre-print "The Lure of Counterfactual Curiosity" (DOI: https://doi.org/10.31219/osf.io/jm3uc). These studies address the question of whether people seek post-decision counterfactual information - how much they could have won - in a gambling task (the Balloon Analogue Risk Task, BART; Lejuez et al., 2002). In previous studies we used a within-participant design, presenting participants with 60 trials of the BART and giving them the option to view the balloon's limit after each trial. Participants frequently sought information even at some cost even though a. it made them feel bad, and b. (we argue that) it had no instrumental value. Our argument that the information had no instrumental value relied on the independent nature of the trials in the task - since the balloon's limit was randomly determined on each trial - so gaining information about the limit on the previous trial cannot benefit performance on future trials. However, it may be argued that participants believe that there is some non-random structure that can be learned through seeking information about the balloon's limit. Thus, they might have sought information for instrumental reasons, even though the information was actually not of any instrumental value. 

In the current study, we aim to demonstrate that people will still incur costs to learn post-decision counterfactual information when the possibility to use that information in the future is completely removed because there is only one trial and that information still makes them feel bad. In the new version of the task, participants practice by completing 10 trials of the BART with no option to seek information. They rate their emotions on a visual analogue scale after seeing the outcome of each trial. 

After the 10 practice trials, participants receive the following instructions: "Now that you've had a chance to practice, it's time for the real thing! There is one more round and this time each pump is worth 20p!". They then complete one critical round of the BART. If participants 'go bust' on this final round, then they do not get a bonus payment and they are not offered the opportunity to see how far they could have gone. If they 'banked' the money, then after rating their emotions about the outcome, then they are given the following instructions: "You won £X.XX. Would you like to see how much you could have won if you kept going? The information comes at a price - you will have to wait 30 seconds for your completion code at the end of the experiment! Press Y for yes or N for no.". 

If they choose to see the information, then they see an animation of the balloon inflating to its randomly determined limit and are presented with information about how much money they could have won on the trial. If they choose not to receive the information then they continue to observe their obtained outcome for the same time as if they had chosen to view the information. Participants then rate their emotions a second time. This second emotion rating is the critical dependent variable.

other.value:
Data collection before the study: 
Data from 18 participants has been collected in a pilot phase to determine whether people are willing to wait 30 seconds at the end of the experiment in return for seeing the balloon's limit. Of those 18 participants, 10 participants stopped before the balloon's limit so banked the money. Of those, 8 sought information about how much they could have won, and 2 did not seek information. The remaining 8 participants 'went bust' so were not given the opportunity to see the balloon's limit. These pilot participants will not be included in the final sample. From this pilot phase we determined that the parameters of our design are suitable to elicit both choices to and not to seek information. This is crucial for comparing emotion ratings between those who did and did not seek information. No other designs were piloted.

Additional analyses planned:
Following our previous analyses, we will determine the effect of the size of the missed opportunity on emotion ratings for those who observed the missed opportunity while controlling for the number of pumps. We will also run the same analysis on those who did not seek information as a check for any statistical artefacts (we do not expect to see any effect since participants did not observe the missed opportunity).

Additionally, we are interested in the change in emotion rating that the information brought, so we will compare difference scores between the two information ratings between participants who did and did not seek information.

sample.value: We will collect data from 360 adult participants using the participant recruitment platform Prolific.co. Based on our previous studies using a within-participant design, we expected to see a medium to large effect of counterfactual information seeking on emotion ratings. Based on our pilot data (described below), we expected an uneven distribution between those who sought and those who did not seek information. We used G-Power to determine the sample size required for the between subjects t-test with uneven groups. We used the following parameters: tails = 2; Cohen's d = 0.5; alpha = 0.05; power = 0.8; Allocation ration N2/N1 = 0.25. This gives a minimum sample of 200 participants. Note that this analysis will only contain participants who did not 'go bust'. In our pilot, 8 out of 18 participants 'went bust', we will thus increase our sample by an additional 160 participants to achieve the required number of participants who do not go bust.

outliers.value:
Unlike in our previous experiments, participants who 'go bust' in the critical trial will not be offered the chance to see how far they could have inflated the balloon, so will not be included in the analysis. We decided not to use 'false feedback' to ensure that all participants banked in the task because we did not want to deceive the participants in any way during this task. We were concerned that using false feedback may introduce statistical artefacts into our design because of potential biases in participants' bidding behaviour.

The recruitment platform pre-screened participants for English as a first language before participation to ensure easy understanding of the task instructions.

dependent.value: Emotion ratings measured on a visual analogue scale will be compared between participants who chose to learn how much they could have won and those who did not.

conditions.value: There is not straightforward condition assignment. Each trial has a randomly determined 'safe limit' (sampled from a uniform distribution between 0 and 12) and the outcome of the trial is determined by whether the participant's bid (i.e. the number of inflations of the balloon they make) exceeds that number. So on some trials the balloon would burst after just one pump, and on others it would not burst after 12 (the maximum number) of pumps. This is randomly determined in the experiment script. Participants can choose whether they wish to seek information (the independent variable in our main emotion rating analysis), so this is outside the control of the experiment. The amount of money the participant missed out on (the missed opportunity they can learn about) is determined by a combination of the participant's bid and the randomly determined safe limit of the balloon.

hypothesis.value: Do people who seek counterfactual information feel worse than those who do not seek counterfactual information?

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name:
Counterfactual Curiosity - One-shot Task

This experiment is a follow-up to the five experiments reported in our pre-print "The Lure of Counterfactual Curiosity" (DOI: https://doi.org/10.31219/osf.io/jm3uc). These studies address the question of whether people seek post-decision counterfactual information - how much they could have won - in a gambling task (the Balloon Analogue Risk Task, BART; Lejuez et al., 2002). In previous studies we used a within-participant design, presenting participants with 60 trials of the BART and giving them the option to view the balloon's limit after each trial. Participants frequently sought information even at some cost even though a. it made them feel bad, and b. (we argue that) it had no instrumental value. Our argument that the information had no instrumental value relied on the independent nature of the trials in the task - since the balloon's limit was randomly determined on each trial - so gaining information about the limit on the previous trial cannot benefit performance on future trials. However, it may be argued that participants believe that there is some non-random structure that can be learned through seeking information about the balloon's limit. Thus, they might have sought information for instrumental reasons, even though the information was actually not of any instrumental value. 

In the current study, we aim to demonstrate that people will still incur costs to learn post-decision counterfactual information when the possibility to use that information in the future is completely removed because there is only one trial and that information still makes them feel bad. In the new version of the task, participants practice by completing 10 trials of the BART with no option to seek information. They rate their emotions on a visual analogue scale after seeing the outcome of each trial. 

After the 10 practice trials, participants receive the following instructions: "Now that you've had a chance to practice, it's time for the real thing! There is one more round and this time each pump is worth 20p!". They then complete one critical round of the BART. If participants 'go bust' on this final round, then they do not get a bonus payment and they are not offered the opportunity to see how far they could have gone. Would you like to see how much you could have won if you kept going? The information comes at a price - you will have to wait 30 seconds for your completion code at the end of the experiment! Press Y for yes or N for no.". 

If they choose to see the information, then they see an animation of the balloon inflating to its randomly determined limit and are presented with information about how much money they could have won on the trial. If they choose not to receive the information then they continue to observe their obtained outcome for the same time as if they had chosen to view the information. Each trial has a randomly determined 'safe limit' (sampled from a uniform distribution between 0 and 12) and the outcome of the trial is determined by whether the participant's bid (i.e. the number of inflations of the balloon they make) exceeds that number. attributes.title: Girls with guns? How culture shapes perceptions of females in the military.

q1.value: Girls with guns? How culture shapes perceptions of females in the military.

q3.value: As shown by Boldry et al. (2001) women in a cadet school were perceived as less competent, yet higher in warmth than men, though their actual competence was not significantly different than their male counterparts. This result is congruent with findings presented in a vast literature on Stereotype Content Model – in many contexts women are perceived as less competent, yet warmer than men. In this study, we examine the differences in perception of women in the military between two countries, namely Israel and Poland. Israel is the only country in the world with compulsory military service for women (Sasson-Levy, 2011). We argue that there are certain qualities that make Israeli context unique comparing to other countries and that these qualities will lead to differences in perceptions of women between Polish and Israeli participants. Specifically, we hypothesize that perceived competence and perceived warmth of women in the military context will be higher in Israel than in Poland.

q4.value:
1. Because of prevalence of experience of women in decisive roles in the military setting, perceived competence of women in military context will be higher in Israel than in Poland
2. Perceived warmth will also be higher in Israel than in Poland - although the military context may decrease perceived warmth, frequent experience of women in military uniforms and women carrying guns will suppress decrease in warmth perception in Israelis due to mere exposure effect (Zajonc, 1968). 
3. We predict that perceptions of warmth and competence will be moderated by scores on Ambivalent Sexism Inventory (Glick Fiske, 1997)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
This study is a part of a bigger research project, in which participants from two countries (Poland and Israel) recruited through survey panel will fill out multiple questionnaires regarding various socio-psychological topics.
Our study has between-subject design. Participants will answer questions through Qualtrics Survey platform. Subjects will be randomly assigned to a condition, which will determine the type of picture they will be shown: pictures of women in uniforms, men in uniforms, women in civilian clothes, men in civilian clothes. Each participant sees only one picture, in regard to which questions are asked.

q9.value: There is a random assignment (performed on the level of Qualtrics) to one of 4 conditions of  picture type shown. Given the sample of 1000 + 1000, that gives 250 + 250 participants per picture type.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data for this study will be collected as a part of a bigger research project. The whole survey consists of 146 and 142 questions in Polish and Hebrew respectively.
Data will be collected by two nation-wide panels: Ariadna (Poland) and Midgam (Israel). Each panel agreed to provide a representative sample consisting of 1000 participants.

Exclusion criteria:
Incomplete responses will be removed. 
If an observation will be removed due to any other criterion at later stages, it will be explicitly marked in the manuscript and two alternative versions of data analysis will be provided - with and without an exclusion.

q13.value:
We assume n = 1000 based on our contracts with Ariadna (Poland) and Midgam (Israel) panels. The assumed structure of the sample will be as follows:
- n1 = 1000 - a representative sample of Polish participants
- n2 = 1000 - a representative sample of Israeli participants

q14.value: The sample size for our study is driven by a sample size of the whole project.

question.value: The manipulated variable is assignment to a particular picture type.  There are 4 levels of this variable: pictures of women in uniforms, men in uniforms, women in normal clothes, men in normal clothes. For each picture type, there is a pool of 3 pictures, from which one picture is drawn.

1) ABC/SCM (Koch et al., 2016) regarding the person shown in the picture (how friendly/unfriendly, competent/incompetent, liberal/conservative on a 1-7 Likert scale). Generating mesures of: competence, warmth, progressiveness. 
2) Applied/embedded questions referring to SCM - how good of a parent/manager a person from the picture would be.
3) ASI - Ambivalent sexism Inventory (Glick, Fiske; 1997). Outcome measure as two average scores: benevolent sexism and hostile sexism. ASI can be a moderator of perceived competence and warmth of our targets.

1) ABC/SCM. Outcome measure: each of 3 pairs of questions will be calculated into an average for categories: competent, warm, progressive. The results will be displayed on a two-dimensional scale. It’s a mix of SCM and ABC, so we will check for both SCM: warmth & competence model, and for ABC: competence & progressiveness, where warmth (community) is an emergent quality in the two-dimensional space of competence & progressiveness. 

2) Outcome measure as two numerical variables: one for embedded competence (manager) and one for embedded warmth (parent).

3) ASI. Outcome measure as two average scores: benevolent sexism and hostile sexism (calculated according to the scale instructions).

We plan to use the following random-effects models to test our hypotheses (R pseudocode):

warmth ~ country + gender + (1| picture)
competence ~ country + gender + (1| picture)
[warmth / competence] ~ country * ASI + gender + (1|picture)

q24.value: We assume that participant’s conservatism/liberalism (as measured by ABC (Koch et al., 2016) scale) can be a moderator of the relationship between subject's country of origin and target perceptions.

registration_responses.q1: Girls with guns? How culture shapes perceptions of females in the military.

Specifically, we hypothesize that perceived competence and perceived warmth of women in the military context will be higher in Israel than in Poland.

summary.value:
This work investigates the influence of generous gestures in volatile human intelligence (HUMINT) gathering interactions. Here, intelligence refers to information relevant to national or international security provided by a human source (see, also, Hartwig et al., 2014). An essential aspect of HUMINT gathering involves a handler establishing an arrangement with a source. In an intelligence arrangement, a handler  is a party seeking the information. A source is a party possessing the information. This research examines whether a generous gesture by a handler influences how favorably a source perceives the handler—specifically, the extent to which a source perceives a handler as respectful, trustworthy, and professional. Handlers have reported capitalizing on these perceptions to facilitate sources’ cooperation (see, e.g., Redlich et al., 2014; Russano et al., 2014; Soufan, 2011). Cooperation means assisting the handler to gain whatever information that the source can truthfully help with.

The attached document provides the research design, hypothesis, and analysis plans in full detail.

registration_responses.summary:
This work investigates the influence of generous gestures in volatile human intelligence (HUMINT) gathering interactions. Here, intelligence refers to information relevant to national or international security provided by a human source (see, also, Hartwig et al., 2014). An essential aspect of HUMINT gathering involves a handler establishing an arrangement with a source. In an intelligence arrangement, a handler  is a party seeking the information. A source is a party possessing the information. This research examines whether a generous gesture by a handler influences how favorably a source perceives the handler—specifically, the extent to which a source perceives a handler as respectful, trustworthy, and professional. Handlers have reported capitalizing on these perceptions to facilitate sources’ cooperation (see, e.g., Redlich et al., 2014; Russano et al., 2014; Soufan, 2011). Cooperation means assisting the handler to gain whatever information that the source can truthfully help with.

The attached document provides the research design, hypothesis, and analysis plans in full detail.

attributes.title: The Impact of Clickbait for Media Choice

q1.value: The Impact of Clickbait for Media Choice

q5.value: Thanks to the Knight Foundation for their grant to Nate Persily at Stanford for financing this research.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We study the effect of clickbait on media choice.

q16.value: We randomly assign subjects to one of 4 treatment conditions or a placebo condition: negative fact--D partisan: Trump economic policies not working positive fact--R partisan: Trump economic policies working negative fact--D partisan clickbait: Republicans won’t like this economic news: Trump policies not working! positive fact--R partisan clickbait: Democrats won’t like this economic news: Trump policies working! We then measure affective polarization (feeling thermometers for the two parties), trust in online/traditional media, and factual knowledge retention (3 questions from the text of the story they read). R-partisan condition: increase estimation of Rs D-partisan condition: decrease estimation of Rs Clickbait: amplify effects of D/R partisan conditions Clickbait: decrease trust in (online) media Clickbait: increase information retention We also estimate a pre-treatment "preference for clickbait" by having respondents choose which headlines they want to read: Effects of clickbait will be larger for people with a higher preference for clickbait.

q17.value: Difference in means, or multivariate OLS, depending on the functional form.

registration_responses.q1: The Impact of Clickbait for Media Choice
registration_responses.q5: Thanks to the Knight Foundation for their grant to Nate Persily at Stanford for financing this research.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: We study the effect of clickbait on media choice.
registration_responses.q16: We randomly assign subjects to one of 4 treatment conditions or a placebo condition: negative fact--D partisan: Trump economic policies not working positive fact--R partisan: Trump economic policies working negative fact--D partisan clickbait: Republicans won’t like this economic news: Trump policies not working! positive fact--R partisan clickbait: Democrats won’t like this economic news: Trump policies working! We then measure affective polarization (feeling thermometers for the two parties), trust in online/traditional media, and factual knowledge retention (3 questions from the text of the story they read). R-partisan condition: increase estimation of Rs D-partisan condition: decrease estimation of Rs Clickbait: amplify effects of D/R partisan conditions Clickbait: decrease trust in (online) media Clickbait: increase information retention We also estimate a pre-treatment "preference for clickbait" by having respondents choose which headlines they want to read: Effects of clickbait will be larger for people with a higher preference for clickbait.
registration_responses.q17: Difference in means, or multivariate OLS, depending on the functional form.

attributes.title: Misinformation, Threat, and Public Support for Free Trade

q1.value: Misinformation, Threat, and Public Support for Free Trade

q2.value: D.J. Flynn | Yusaku Horiuchi | Dong Zhang

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Trade is an increasingly salient policy issue in the United States. A large literature investigates the origins of public preferences on trade policy. Most existing research argues that people’s preferences for free trade or protectionism stem largely from two factors: (1) rational self-interest and (2) anxiety/uncertainty about the effects of trade. In this project, we investigate the influence of two factors -- factual misperceptions and threat perceptions -- on trade policy preferences. We examine the influence of misperceptions and threat on beliefs and opinions about trade using a survey experiment conducted on an existing panel of Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) participants (more information on sample is provided below).

q16.value: H1: Misinformation about Chinese currency manipulation will reduce support for free trade. H2: Priming people to view China as economically threatening will reduce support for free trade. H3: A correction pointing out that China is not currently manipulating its currency will increase belief accuracy. H4: The effect of a correction pointing out that China is not currently manipulating its currency on belief accuracy will be attenuated when people are primed to view China as economically threatening. Research questions: We also examine whether the effects above vary depending on participants’ pre-treatment characteristics (e.g., demographics, partisanship, beliefs about the effects of trade, beliefs about the size of the Chinese economy, ethnocentrism). We do not offer theoretical predictions on these moderation effects.

q19.value: 2,994 participants will be invited (final N will depend on response rate)

summary.value: The purpose of this registration is to time-stamp the arrival of ethics committee approval papers for the Moscow center, which will hopefully start inclusions in the near future.
